title: ‘Landslide’: Santana beats out Baker, Wu says, while Culpepper wins D7
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: Rev. Miniard Culpepper secures District 7 seat on Boston City Council, defeating Said Ahmed by a significant margin.
At-large City Councilor Henry Santana wins reelection, beating former Councilor Frank Baker in a reported landslide.
All incumbent district councilors in Boston return to their seats, ensuring stability in the council lineup for next year.

title: Jake Wilson to be Somerville’s next mayor, unofficial results show
author: Sana Muneer
bullets: Jake Wilson won the Somerville mayoral race with 11,185 votes, defeating Willie Burnley Jr., who received 9,054.
Wilson's campaign focused on improving city services to address housing, street safety, and rodent issues.
Wilson has a background in media and communications and served as a city councilor and non-profit leader.

title: Lowell police seeking public’s help with details about fatal hit-and-run
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Lowell police seek information on fatal hit-and-run incident that occurred on Oct. 30 on Chelmsford Street.
The victim, a woman, received emergency treatment but was pronounced dead at a local hospital shortly after.
Police have located the vehicle involved but request public help; contact Lowell police at 978-937-3200.

title: ‘This is just the beginning’: Nonbinding Israel divestment ballot question passes in Somerville
author: Sana Muneer
bullets: Somerville voters passed a nonbinding ballot question to divest from companies supporting Israel's actions in Palestine, with 55.7% voting in favor.
The measure, driven by the Somerville for Palestine group, aims to influence local officials to boycott companies linked to Israel.
Somerville United Against Discrimination opposed the ballot, citing community division and a lawsuit attempt to block the measure was unsuccessful.

title: Tom Brady just revealed that his dog Junie is a clone of Lua, his deceased furry friend
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Tom Brady cloned his deceased dog Lua, creating a dog named Junie with Colossal Biosciences, a company he invested in.
Colossal Biosciences, launched in 2021, partnered with Viagen, a leading animal cloning company founded in 2002.
Colossal announced achievements like genetically engineering wolves and aims to advance de-extinction and species preservation efforts.

title: Running unopposed, Michelle Wu secures second term as her national profile grows
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: Boston Mayor Michelle Wu wins a second term after running unopposed in the November election.
Wu initially defeated opponent Josh Kraft by nearly 50 points, leading to his withdrawal in September.
Wu's national profile has grown, especially after testifying to Congress regarding Boston's sanctuary policies.

title: Tell us: What should Mayor Wu focus on in her second term?
author: Annie Jonas
bullets: Mayor Michelle Wu begins her second term after running unopposed in the November 2025 election.
Housing affordability and climate resiliency were major focuses in Wu's previous term, with ongoing high housing costs in Boston.
Community input is being sought on whether Wu should prioritize public safety, transit, or other local issues in her new term.

title: ‘This is kidnapping — plain and simple’: ICE arrests 9 employees at Allston car wash
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: ICE agents detained nine employees at Allston Car Wash despite them having work permits, according to the manager.
The raid involved 22 federal agents, who allegedly did not allow workers to retrieve documents due to a language barrier.
Boston City Councilor Liz Breadon condemned the ICE raid, calling it 'kidnapping,' and urged contacting local support organizations.

title: Patriots opt to stand pat at trade deadline
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: The New England Patriots chose not to make any trades at the NFL deadline, retaining their current roster.
The team's decision comes despite losing players Keion White and Kyle Dugger, which affected their defensive depth.
With a 7-2 record, the Patriots focus on sustainable growth, avoiding short-term trades involving high draft picks.

title: Amid SNAP benefit cuts, these Greater Boston food businesses are here to help
author: Katelyn Umholtz
bullets: Greater Boston food businesses are providing assistance amid SNAP benefit cuts during the ongoing federal government shutdown.
Community efforts include free meals, meal deals, and community fridges, supported by donations and local partnerships.
Key participants include Allandale Farm, American Flatbread, Blacker’s Bakeshop, and other local food businesses.
